summary.Presentation: The Department of History and Classical Studies at Aarhus University invites applications for an Editor and Project Co-ordinator for a full time position from 1 September 2022 – 31 December 2023.

JobPositionInformation.Purpose:
The Department of History and Classical Studies at Aarhus University invites applications for an Editor and Project Co-ordinator for a full time position from 1 September 2022 – 31 December 2023.

The New Nordic Lexicon/nordics.info

The position is funded by a grant from the A.P. Møller and Chastine McKinney Møller Foundation to work on a specific project, ‘The New Nordic Lexicon’. The New Nordic Lexicon will be an accessible, free, online resource of 50 exclusively Nordic terms and concepts, together with with 15 podcasts and 10 films. It aims to disseminate relevant and up-to-date research within the humanities and social sciences on fundamental aspects of Nordic history, culture and society. The main target groups are young people and those in their twenties in the Nordics, as well as students and educational institutions, but it will also be a valuable resource for anyone interested in Norden.

The project will be developed as part of nordics.info, which is a public website disseminating reliable, research-based information on the politics, society, history and culture of the Nordic countries, through different media including articles, short films and podcasts. Nordics.info was launched in 2019 as part of the Nordic University Hub ReNEW (Reimagining Norden in an Evolving World), funded by NordForsk 2018-2024 and involving six universities across the Nordic region. The editor and project co-ordinator is based at the School of Culture and Society at Aarhus University but will work closely with colleagues at AU and the other universities participating in the hub. The New Nordic Lexicon will be developed in partnership with ReNEW colleagues at Aarhus University, Helsinki University, Södertörn University and University of Oslo.

The postholder will be based at the Department of History’s offices in Nobelparken, Jens Christian Skous vej 5, 8000 Aarhus C. The position will also involve some travel in the Nordic region.

Job description

The editor and project co-ordinator will take responsibility for all phases of The New Nordic Lexicon project, including the following:
  • identification of key terms through consultation with researchers, facilitation of focus groups and analysis of the results;
  • commissioning, editing and translation of articles;
  • design and development of online platform, ensuring compliance with institutional requirements for accessibility;
  • recording, producing and editing podcasts and short films;
  • communications, social media and outreach work to publicise project;
  • analysis and evaluation of the project.
The editor and project co-ordinator will work closely together with academic and technical support staff, including with researchers from different universities across the Nordic region, and will also recruit and manage student interns and assistants. In addition the postholder will continue to work with colleagues in the ReNEW hub on the further development of nordics.info.

The job therefore entails a variety of assignments and tasks, sometimes with short deadlines, requiring an ability to juggle several tasks simultaneously while not compromising the quality of work or losing track of details. A sharp eye for editorial detail is essential, as is the ability to communicate clearly and professionally with a range of partners and collaborators, in Danish (or Scandinavian) and English.

Qualifications 

The successful applicant will have:
  • An MA qualification in any relevant academic discipline (arts, humanities or social sciences).
  • Evidence of expertise/interest in the broad area of Nordic studies and the Nordic region.
  • Excellent written and spoken communication skills including native or near native competence in written English; competence in at least one of the Scandinavian languages (Danish, Norwegian or Swedish).
  • Experience of editorial work in different media, including production and editing of podcasts and short films. Experience of using Premier Pro or similar.
  • Experience of and interest in public engagement and research dissemination.
  • Ability to work independently and as part of a team, communicating with researchers at all career stages across a variety of disciplines
  • Excellent IT competences, including experience of working with CMS (Typo3) and Google Analytics.
  • Experience with fundraising and reporting.


Application procedure 

The application must be written in English and should include the following:
  • A personal statement of no more than 1 page stating the reasons for applying and demonstrating suitability for the position
  • Curriculum vitae
  • Transcripts and degree certificates


Further information

For further information about the position, please contact Professor Mary Hilson; email mary.hilson@cas.au.dk.    

If you have any questions about the recruitment process, please contact the HR Department: HR supporter Marianne Birn, email: mbb@au.dk
 

Department of History and Classical Studies

In the history programme at Aarhus University we study the past to understand the present. A thorough knowledge of the past is an important tool for understanding ourselves and the world that we live in. Knowledge of the past provides depth and breadth; it allows us to look beyond the current agenda and put the world in perspective. Studying history does not provide definitive answers to contemporary dilemmas, but it does offer us the opportunity to engage in a continuous dialogue about how the world obtained its present shape, and how we have become who we are.

The School of Culture and Society

At the School of Culture and Society, the object of research and teaching is the interplay between culture and society in time and space:
  • From the traditional disciplines of the humanities and theology to applied social research
  • From Antiquity to the issues facing contemporary societies
  • From local questions to global challenges
The school’s ambition is to produce compelling research with an international resonance as well as to offer teaching and talent development of the highest quality. The school has a broad cooperative interface with society as a whole, both in Denmark and abroad, and contributes to social innovation, research communication and further and continuing education.

For further information about the school, please see http://cas.au.dk/en/.
 


Salary and terms of employment

In accordance with the current collective agreement between the Ministry of Finance and the Danish Confederation of Professional Associations (Akademikerne)

Aarhus University’s ambition is to be an attractive and inspiring workplace for all and to foster a culture in which each individual has opportunities to thrive, achieve and develop.

We view equality and diversity as assets, and we welcome all applicants.




Faculty of Arts

The Faculty of Arts is one of five main academic areas at Aarhus University.

The faculty contributes to Aarhus University's research, talent development, knowledge exchange and degree programmes.
With its 550 academic staff members, 275 PhD students, 9,500 BA and MA students, and 1,500 students following continuing/further education programmes, the faculty constitutes a strong and diverse research and teaching environment.

The Faculty of Arts consists of the School of Communication and Culture, the School of Culture and Society and the Danish School of Education. Each of these units has strong academic environments and forms the basis for interdisciplinary research and education.

The faculty's academic environments and degree programmes engage in international collaboration and share the common goal of contributing to the development of knowledge, welfare and culture in interaction with society.

Read more at arts.au.dk/en

The application must be submitted via Aarhus University’s recruitment system, which can be accessed under the job advertisement on Aarhus University's website.
 
Aarhus University is an academically diverse and research-intensive university with a strong commitment to high-quality research and education and the development of society nationally and globally. The university offers an inspiring research and teaching environment to its 38,000 students (FTEs) and 8,000 employees, and has an annual revenues of EUR 885 million. Learn more at www.international.au.dk/
